entry.title: Browser Content Area in Enable Now is capturing entire browser
entry.content: For the past week or so, we've been experiencing an issue where selecting Browser Content Area (as we always have) is capturing the entire browser (similar to Active Window) and not just the content. This happens in both Chrome and Edge...I've tried uninstalling and reinstalling the extensions, clearing the browser cache and cookies, but nothing has worked...I'd guess this was due to a browser update, but for it to happen in both browsers makes it seem unlikely. For the time being, we are using the Region option and manually sizing the capture area to fit the content. This is causing much frustration in our projects and we are desperately trying to find a solution for this.

entry.title: Making Sense of Sales Org Structures in SAP: Sales, Sales Org, Sales Office, and Sales Group
entry.content:
When you first look at sales structures in SAP, the terms can feel like they‚Äôre all saying the same thing. Sales Org, Sales Office, Sales Group, Sales Unit‚Äîit‚Äôs easy to get lost. Let‚Äôs break it down in a way that actually makes sense.

1. Sales Org, Sales Office, Sales Group ‚Äì the classics
Think of these as the traditional building blocks. They‚Äôve been around in ERP and S/4 forever, and they have specific meanings:

  • Sales Organization: The top level. Usually tied to a country or a large region, like ‚ÄúGermany Sales Org.‚Äù It‚Äôs also important in transactions (pricing, master data, sales orders, etc.).

  • Sales Office: A sub-level, often representing a physical office, like ‚ÄúBerlin Sales Office.‚Äù

  • Sales Group: Even more granular, like ‚ÄúNorth Berlin Sales Group‚Äù inside that office.

These units are embedded into the system. They show up in transactions, master data, and user assignments. If a sales rep is tied to a Sales Group, that info automatically flows into quotes, orders, and reporting.

2. Sales Unit ‚Äì the flexible layer
Now here‚Äôs the modern twist: Sales Unit is like a flexible overlay that lets you model your structure more creatively. It‚Äôs not bound by the strict definitions of Org, Office, or Group.

Why use it?

  • You want reporting across multiple orgs (e.g., ‚ÄúEurope Sales‚Äù across five countries).

  • You want to add dimensions that aren‚Äôt in your backend (e.g., splitting one office into ‚ÄúInternet Sales‚Äù vs. ‚ÄúDirect Sales‚Äù).

  • You want to restructure without touching the ERP backbone.

In short: Sales Units let you go beyond the rigid ERP structure.

3. How they work together
Here‚Äôs the simplest way to think of it:

  • Sales Org / Office / Group = specific, traditional sales units that matter for master and transaction data.

  • Sales Unit = the superset that gives you finer granularity and flexibility.

When you assign a user to a Sales Unit and they create a sales document (like a quote), the system knows the hierarchy. It pulls in the related Sales Group, Office, and Org automatically.

So what‚Äôs the takeaway?

  • If you‚Äôre defining legal and transactional structures, stick to Sales Org, Office, and Group.

  • If you‚Äôre defining reporting and flexible structures, use Sales Units.

That‚Äôs it. No need to overcomplicate. Think of Sales Units as your way to model the real-world sales structure without being trapped by backend constraints.

entry.title: Re: PGI and PGR in Advanced Returns Management (ARM)
entry.content:
Why PGI works differently in ARM is because, in classic returns, the system treats the SD-FC (Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge) order as a standalone replenishment. You can upload stock directly to the SD-FC sales order item and execute PGI without issue.

But in ARM, the SD-FC order is logistically and financially linked to the original return order. This linkage is managed through the follow-up activity and returns document flow, which changes how inventory is tracked and consumed.

What is happening behind the scenes is when you create a return order in ARM, the returned goods are received into blocked stock (typically via movement type 653). The system tracks this blocked stock against the return sales order and item, not the SD-FC order. When you create the SD-FC order, it inherits the reference to the return order. But the system expects the PGI to consume stock from the return order, not from a fresh upload to the SD-FC order. So when you upload stock against the SD-FC order directly, the system doesn‚Äôt recognize it as valid for PGI‚Äîbecause it‚Äôs not part of the ARM-managed return flow.

What you can do is if you want PGI to work smoothly in ARM:

  • Always upload or adjust stock against the return order and item.
  • Ensure the follow-up activity in the ARM return order is correctly set to ‚ÄúSubsequent Delivery Free of Charge.‚Äù
  • Use transaction MSR_INSPWH if inspection is involved, to release stock from blocked to unrestricted before PGI.

entry.title: UI5 Routing Issue in Multi-Page Custom Plugin for SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I‚Äôm experiencing an issue when using a custom plugin with multiple pages in SAP Digital Manufacturing. When I route between pages, the ‚ÄúThe requested page is not available‚Äù bypass page briefly appears before the correct page is loaded. This only happens when navigating between subpages. However, when I route back from the Detail view to the MainView, the navigation works correctly without showing the bypass page. The plugin was uploaded properly as an extension in the POD Designer and was created using the Yeoman Generator.

Here are the most important code snippets:

  • manifest.json (1,2)
  • Routing in DetailController.js (3)
  • MainView.view (4)
  • Component.json (5)

Structure:  MainView.view -> Detail.view -> Over.view.

I would appreciate any help or suggestions.

 

 

 

@ManoelCosta   @Kevin_Hunter1

entry.title: Remove Suppress Groovy script for CPI Message Mapping
entry.content:
import com.sap.it.api.mapping.*

def void removeSuppress(String[] values, Output output, MappingContext context) {
def filtered = values.findAll { v -> v != null && !output.isSuppress(v) }
filtered.each { v -> output.addValue(v) }
}

entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud RAP Custom action Print pdf
entry.content:
Hi @JamesG 

To trigger a direct download of a printed Adobe Form (PDF) from the front-end in a RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming Model) Fiori app, instead of just sending it to the print queue, you need to expose the PDF as a stream from your backend action and trigger it from the custom button on your Fiori UI.

Here is the approach I recommend

  • In your RAP behaviour definition (BDEF), ensure the Print action calls the Adobe Form rendering and returns the PDF file content as RAWSTRING (XSTRING).
  • Use Base64 or binary format to transfer the PDF from the ABAP backend to the Fiori front-end.
  • Update your Fiori UI logic so that when the print action is executed, the app receives the file content and opens a browser download using Blob/URL.createObjectURL for binary data.

The following technical steps should support you in that process:

  1. Backend ABAP (RAP) Action:
    • After rendering the Adobe Form, encode the PDF output as Base64 or provide the XSTRING/RAWSTRING in the response payload. An example is to add the file content to an entity or as an action return parameter.
  2. Fiori UI (Front-end):
    • On Print button press, trigger the RAP action and receive the PDF content.
    • Convert Base64/RAWSTRING to blob and use JavaScript to prompt file download or open the PDF directly in a new tab.

Here are some useful References

SAP Q&A: How to create RAP Action to generate a file to download?

Sample workaround for similar download logic.

This process will enable end users to directly download or view the generated PDF from the RAP service without needing to access the print queue.

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Massive update the ATP rule in EDE?
entry.content:
Dear

please read SAP Help Wiki: "How to setup an APO‚ÄëATP example"

Yes, you can massively update ATP rules in EDE via LSMW/FM or custom program, and then request a Master Data Transport TR from /SAPAPO/AC42 (Extras ‚Üí Transport) to move them into GDE.

Do the massive update in EDE via either:

LSMW (using BDC in /SAPAPO/AC42) Or a Z-report using /SAPAPO/RRP_ATP_RULE_SAVE

After update, go to /SAPAPO/AC42 ‚Üí Extras ‚Üí Transport, select updated ATP Rules.

This will create a transport request which you can release and move to GDE.

Best regards

entry.title: Multiple Ways to Give Feedback on CAP Documentation
entry.content:
At CAP, we believe great documentation is a collaborative effort. That's why we've built multiple channels for you to share feedback, report issues, and contribute improvements. Whether you spot a typo, need clarification, or want to suggest new content, we've got you covered.

Quick Feedback: "Was This Page Helpful?

The fastest way to give feedback is right at the bottom of every documentation page.

Our "Was This Page Helpful?" widget lets you:

‚Ä¢ Give a quick üëç or üëé rating.
‚Ä¢ Add optional comments (up to 140 characters, dialog opens after you gave a rating).
‚Ä¢ Track sentiment without leaving the page.

This feedback is collected anonymously through Matomo analytics and helps us identify which pages need attention. It's perfect for quick reactions and brief improvement suggestions.

Targeted Survey Feedback

For more structured feedback, click the survey icon in the top navigation bar. 

This links to our comprehensive SAP Insights survey where you can:

‚Ä¢ Rate different aspects of the documentation.
‚Ä¢ Suggest specific improvements.
‚Ä¢ Share your overall experience with CAP.
‚Ä¢ Provide demographic information to help us understand our audience.

The survey typically takes 5-10 minutes and gives us deeper insights into what's working and what needs improvement. Not only for capire but also for CAP overall.

Issues & Bug Reports: GitHub Issues

Found a problem? Have a feature request? Head to our GitHub Issues page.

This is ideal for:

‚Ä¢ Bug reports: Broken links, incorrect code examples, outdated information
‚Ä¢ Content requests: Missing documentation, unclear explanations
‚Ä¢ Technical issues: Problems with the website functionality
‚Ä¢ Enhancement suggestions: Ideas for improving existing content

GitHub Issues provide full transparency - you can see what others have reported and track progress on fixes.

Direct Contributions: Edit This Page

See something that needs a quick fix? At the bottom of every page is an "Edit this page" link that takes you directly to GitHub.

There you can:

‚Ä¢ Fix typos and formatting issues.
‚Ä¢ Update code examples.
‚Ä¢ Add clarifications.
‚Ä¢ Improve explanations.

This leverages GitHub's collaborative features. The process is as follows:

1. Fork the repository
2. Make your changes
3. Submit a pull request
4. Get your improvements reviewed and merged

Learning Resources & Community Contributions

We maintain a curated collection of community learning resources. You can nominate blog posts, tutorials, and other content that helped you learn CAP through GitHub Issues. Tag your issue with suggestions for the learning resources page.

Contributing to Open Source Projects

Many CAP components are open source with their own feedback channels:

‚Ä¢ CDS Database Services: Feature requests and bug reports for database connectors
‚Ä¢ CDS Types: TypeScript declaration improvements
‚Ä¢ IntelliJ Plugin: IDE integration feedback

Which Channel Should You Use?

Use the page widget when:

‚Ä¢ You want to quickly rate a page.
‚Ä¢ You have brief suggestions (under 140 characters).
‚Ä¢ You don't need to track the response.

Use the survey when:

‚Ä¢ You want to provide comprehensive feedback.
‚Ä¢ You have time for a detailed questionnaire.
‚Ä¢ You want to influence our documentation strategy.

Use GitHub Issues when:

‚Ä¢ You found a bug or technical problem.
‚Ä¢ You need to include screenshots or code examples.
‚Ä¢ You want to track progress on your request.
‚Ä¢ You're suggesting new content or major changes.

Use "Edit this page" when:

‚Ä¢ You can fix the issue yourself.
‚Ä¢ The change is straightforward (typos, small clarifications).
‚Ä¢ You want to contribute directly to the codebase.

What Happens Next?

Your feedback doesn't go into a black hole! Here's how we process it:

1. Page ratings are monitored weekly to identify problematic content.
2. Survey responses inform our quarterly documentation roadmap.
3. GitHub Issues are triaged and assigned to subject matter experts if needed.
4. Pull requests are reviewed by maintainers and merged when appropriate.
5. Community contributions are highlighted in our release notes.

Get Involved!

The CAP documentation is a community effort. Whether you're fixing a typo or contributing a comprehensive guide, every improvement helps thousands of developers worldwide.

Ready to contribute? Start with something small - maybe rate this blog post or leave us a comment. Every
contribution makes CAP better for everyone.

Have ideas for improving our feedback mechanisms? We'd love to hear them! Use any of the channels above to let us know.

entry.title: New feature for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration: custom preprocessing exit
entry.content:
As mentioned in my last blog post New integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration, we have deprecated the previous package  Process Integration Pipeline - Generic Integration Flows & Templates and have shipped four new packages replacing the deprecated package for supporting the Pipeline for Cloud Integration. You will notice that the previous package has the label [DEPRECATED] in its name now. No worries, you can still run the old package in a transition phase, if you run the latest update you will notice that just the name has been changed. But we encourage you to switch to the new packages, see Pipelines about how to proceed.

One more reason for switching to the new packages, besides the higher flexibility for setting up different pipelines, is that from now on we ship new features in the new packages only. One of the new features that we have lately shipped is the support for custom preprocessing. You have the option to call a custom exit integration flow without having to edit the provided generic flows. To do so, you must implement a separate integration flow that can be called at the very beginning of each generic integration flow. See Custom Preprocessing Exit.

Let me show you how to configure the custom preprocessing. You have two options, either configure it globally, which means that the custom exit integration flow is called for all of your integration scenarios, or configure it scenario-specific. You can even combine both options, having one global custom exit which is applied across all scenarios and in addition calling scenario-specific exit flows for particular scenarios only.

Global setting

To enable custom preprocessing globally, you need to configure each generic integration flow that should call the custom preprocessing flow as follows:

In the configuration, change the value of the parameter CustomXPreGlobal_Enabled from false (which is the default) to true. Furthermore, maintain the ProcessDirect endpoint of your custom exit integration flow in the parameter CustomXPreGlobal_Endpoint, by default the value is /pip/custom/preProcessing/global. You can keep it or change it to your preference. You may then create one custom integration flow for each generic integration flow of the pipeline or use one single custom integration flow across all pipeline steps depending on your requirements. See also below.

Scenario-specific setting

For scenario-specific configuration, you can define for which pipeline steps the custom exit integration flow should be called. For this, you need to add the corresponding string parameters to the scenario in the Partner Directory for which the custom preprocessing should be enabled.

Create a string parameter CustomXPreEnabled where you define the list of pipeline steps which should call the exit flow separated by pipe.

In our example in the screenshot below, we enable custom preprocessing for all pipeline steps:

  • 01 stands for either the generic XI inbound processing or the generic IDoc inbound processing
  • 02 corresponds to either the generic inbound processing flow or the generic integrated messaging runtime
  • 04 corresponds to the generic receiver determination flow
  • 05 corresponds to the generic interface determination flow
  • 06 corresponds to the generic outbound processing flow

If you run through the integrated messaging runtime, which is our recommended pipeline anyway, only step numbers 01, 02, and 06 are relevant. If you only like to run the custom exit flow for the integrated messaging runtime and the generic outbound processing flow for instance, then set the value to 02|06. I think you get the point.

Furthermore, create a string parameter CustomXPreEndpoint, which points to the ProcessDirect endpoint of your custom exit integration flow. Other than for the global setting, here we only support one custom integration flow across all pipeline steps to minimize the configuration effort, but you can have a separate custom integration flow for each scenario. See how we are able to implement pipeline step specific logic below.

Because we only have one custom integration flow for each scenario, we pass the header customXPipelineStep from the generic flows to the custom flow. With this, you have the option to implement pipeline step specific logic based on this very header. You can use a copy of the template Pipeline v2 Template - Custom Exit to model your custom flow. It contains a router with routes for all pipeline steps including corresponding router conditions. To ensure that the header value is present in the custom flow, the header is part of the allowed headers settings. Furthermore, the template adds the pipeline step number to the custom header properties so that you have full transparency in the message monitor about which pipeline step called the exit flow.

From what we heard from customers, potential use cases could be to implement additional external or internal logging capabilities or to stop certain messages from sending to the receiver systems based on some conditions, e.g. maintained in the Partner Directory. So, regardless of your use case, I think with this we have increased the flexibility of the pipeline for Cloud Integration.

entry.title: Re: S/4 Public Cloud ECS - issue with triggering the ECS...
entry.content:
Hi @Kamen 

Thank you for your question. Hope this still provides some insights to your question.

You are correct that the Error Correction System (ECS) in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is enabled via the app Upload Posting Data, Error Correction and Suspense Accounting. The formatting error you are seeing usually occurs when the CSV/XLSX template is not filled exactly according to the defined structure in the SAP-delivered template. Below are a few checks to carry out:

  1. Template Formatting
    • Ensure you are using the latest template downloaded directly from the app. Please note that templates may change after upgrades.
    • All mandatory columns must be filled. Do not rename or delete columns.
    • Pay attention to the correct date format (YYYY-MM-DD) and amount format (decimal separator as per system settings).
  2. Here are some supported File Types
    • Only CSV UTF-8 or the system-generated XLSX is supported. If you edit in Excel and save in another encoding, the system may reject it.
  3. Interfaces
    • ECS can only be triggered from supported postings via APIs and pre-delivered apps. Custom IDocs/BAPIs are not supported in Public Cloud. Make sure you are using the correct API:
      • Journal Entry Post (Asynchronous) [API_JOURNALENTRYBULK_CREATE]
      • If errors are detected, they flow into ECS automatically.
  4. Some known Limitation
    • Currently, ECS only supports FI postings (GL, AR, AP) and not all submodules. If you are testing with an unsupported posting type, ECS will not trigger.

Below references will provide further guidance

  • Upload Posting Data ‚Äì Error Correction and Suspense Accounting App (F4745)
  • ECS Overview in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Here is my recommendation: Since you already raised an incident, SAP Support will confirm whether it is a template issue or a known bug in your release. In the meantime, re-download the template after your system‚Äôs last upgrade and validate all field formats against the Help Portal documentation.

I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: HR Efficiency in Action: Automate and Streamline HR Processes (APAC/EMEA)
entry.content:
Is your HR team ready to boost efficiency and reduce manual workload‚Äîwhile delivering a better experience to employees and HR team?

Join us for an informative session on driving HR efficiency through automation, smart configuration, and mass data management. We‚Äôll explore how to streamline hiring with tools like configurable hire templates, automatic hire, hiring from position; and mass data management‚Äîplus how AI-powered Joule is transforming employee and manager self-service.

Whether you're leading HR operations, working in HRIS, or driving digital transformation, you'll leave with actionable strategies to simplify workflows, increase productivity, and deliver scalable HR support.

entry.title: Re: How to track *usage* of ESS/MSS (not the resulting data changes)
entry.content:
Hello ,
I Don't think that is doable ? However I can think of utilizing the Workflow!

Tracing by Workflow might provide valuable insights in this scenario. For some customers I‚Äôve worked with, they asked for unifying their Employee Self-Service (ESS) processes under a single workflow, and applying the same approach for Manager Self-Service (MSS). 

By doing so, it becomes much easier to leverage the standard reporting capabilities provided by SAP:

  • If IAS is enabled, the delivered Story Reports offer robust analytics and a clear overview of workflow activity, approval trends, and processing times.
  • If IAS is not enabled, the Canvas Standard Reports are still available, including workflow-specific datasets that support tracking and analysis.

That said, the Story Report option remains my preferred approach, as it provides a more comprehensive and insightful reporting experience.

Best of Luck!

entry.title: Re: Dive into the future of SAP Universal ID and understand the changes underway
entry.content:

entry.title: Re: In ADT, how to display compiler syntax errors inline?...
entry.content:
Here is the option to activate this nice feature in Eclipse menu > Window > Preferences > menu General > Editors > Text Editors > Show code minings for problem annotations ("None" by default, "Errors only", "Errors and Warnings", "Errors, Warnings and Infos" :

This feature is also described here:

  • Semi-automatic custom code adaptation after SAP S/... - SAP Community (2018)
  • Eclipse 2020-03 - what's in it for abapers? - SAP Community

This feature is not described in help.sap.com (or did I miss anything?) It's just talking about the Problems view (Checking ABAP Syntax | SAP Help Portal).

Hi all,

I have an issue where I would like to configure a custom card on the SF Home Page and set its visibility/active period based on the start date of employees.

When I get to the Assignments section of the card configuration I see the below options:

 

When I try to configure it 'Based on Start Date' it does not seem to work.

It only works if the Active period is set to 'Always' or 'Date Range'.

 

I have also come across this particular KBA: 3208257 - Latest Homepage custom cards Based On Start Date is not working for pre day 1 users

entry.title: Joule for Consultants: How small can you start?
entry.content:
Joule for consultant (J4C) is now available for all partners to purchase and use as part of SAP‚Äôs new Per User Per Month (PUPM) price list which was launched some months ago.

The potential benefits are huge!  Consultants at SAP have already used the tool for a long time and experienced great benefits.  Read more about this on pages 7-9 in this document. Further, the pricing of J4C allows even small partners to get going without having to make huge investments and commitments. 

Here are six frequent questions I experience partners are asking:

Do I need to make a big purchase at SAP to get going with Joule for consultants?

No.  With the new PUPM pricing, the minimum purchase requirement is one user.  You pay for it by SAP AI units, which has a minimum purchase requirement of 100 AI units (with a list price of 700 euro).    And with the new ‚Äúper month‚Äù commercial strategy, you can assign/commit J4C users on monthly basis, not yearly basis.  For example, you could potentially start with 1 user for a couple of months.  This limits your initial investment but allows you to start gain value and experiences with the tool.

Is there a Test, Development and Demo (TDD) for Joule for consultants?

No.  The ‚Äútest‚Äù word in ‚ÄúTDD‚Äù is meant for partners to test customer topics in SAP LOB solutions, to be able to support customers as part of SAP‚Äôs offerings.  The situation with J4C is very different: partners will mainly use it themselves in a productive manner related to their own offerings (implementation services).  In this case, a partner as a professional service company is actually a customer of SAP.   That is why J4C is only available on the (productive) customer price list

As a partner, do I need to run an SAP LOB solution productively to install and use J4C?

No.  J4C can run stand-alone, running on a sub account of your global BTP account.  Your consultants will get a URL directly to the BTP J4C instance.  You do not need to run any other productive or TDD system from SAP.

Do I need to run a separate instance of J4C for each of my subsidiaries, or can I run it on one global instance?

You can run it on global level. As J4C is a stand alone solution (thus not related to existing TDD or productive systems), you can potentially run it on global level and provide your world wide consultants with the URL to access it. But note that you need to maintain these users in the IAS instance on SAP BTP where J4C is installed for them to get access to the tool.

What is the best target profile of a resource to use J4C?

The main target is functional and technical implementation consultants, resources who implement and provide support on SAP solutions to customers.   For example, junior consultants often need to learn a lot, they can ask J4C instead of reaching out to senior consultants who often are very busy and hard to get whole of.  Senior consultants can benefit from J4C by finding super specific information fast.  They can also benefit when doing something new at customers.  And they can be ensured they are up to date with the latest changes in SAP for a specific functional topic and following best practices.

Can I sell J4C to my customers? Some of my customers have internal SAP IT departments and/or power users who could benefit.

Yes. You can sell SAP AI units SKU 8019164 to your customers and they can start the activation process of J4C via SAP-for-me. At the moment selling the needed AI Units is possible in a CCFlex motion. Resell motion will become available second half of September.

Summary

In my opinion, starting with J4C is within reach of each SAP partner, and each partner should start on the journey to leverage the tool.

When acquiring J4C, it is important that you as partner know how to purchase AI units, where you what to run J4C (many partners has multiple SAP accounts etc),  you need to understand how to request activation in SAP-for-me, understand how the consumption of the AI units works, and you need to understand how to set J4C up SAP BTP.  For guidance on all these topics, please see this document.

entry.title: Re: Duplicates in draft on test tenant - public cloud
entry.content:
Hello @J-T 

Your draft table was not empty because RAP draft tables are shared across the tenant, not specific to each app. Even though this was your first transport, drafts from other apps were already present, which caused your internal numbering system to clash with them. That is why using late numbering is more reliable. UUIDS are only generated when saving or activating, ensuring uniqueness. Internal numbering might suffice for simple cases, but in production applications, it could have caused the problems you have encountered.

Use sequential numbering for both draft UUID and active UUID whenever ensuring uniqueness is essential.

Example (ABAP RAP, late numbering):

define behaviour for ZI_MYENTITY alias MyEntity

  implementation in class ZBP_MYENTITY unique

  late numbering

{

  create;

  update;

  delete;

  draft enabled;

}

This way, the framework assigns UUIDs when saving, not during draft creation, helping you avoid duplicates across sessions.

Let me know if it helps

Kind regards,
Chuma

entry.title: In a script, how do I check if an LDM Entity is a subtype?
entry.content:
I need to exclude the PKs and PK attributes for Subtype Entities from an export from the LDM, so I'm setting up a computed Boolean extended attribute on the PK. I thought it would be simple but I think I've stumbled across a scripting bug.

It's easy to check for subtypes in the CDM, but the LDM appears to rely on a collection called 'InheritedFrom', which the metamodel documentation says contains 'InheritanceLinks'. However, it also contains every entity that the current entity inherits a FK attribute from. Is there a reliable way of finding out if an entity in the LDM is a subtype?

 

 

'Experimental script

for each myEnt in ActiveModel.Entities
   if myEnt.InheritsFrom is Nothing then ' should only contain InheritanceLinks
      output myEnt
   else
      output myEnt & " is inherited"
      for each myID in myEnt.Identifiers
         if myID.PrimaryIdentifier then
            output myIdentifier
         end if
      next ' identifier
   end if
next ' entity

entry.title: Not able to pick the quantity in the delivery
entry.content:
I am unable to pick the quantity in the delivery. The item category is relevant for picking, and Warehouse Management (WM) is not active for this delivery.

Below is the process I followed:

  1. Created Sales Order with MTO.

  2. Created Delivery and performed PGI (inventory posted against the sales order and line item).

  3. Created Invoice.

  4. Created Return Order.

  5. Performed Delivery and PGR ‚Äì stock was received against the return order and scrapped.

  6. Created Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge Order with reference to the return sales order (Requirement type KE, MTO order).

  7. Created Delivery ‚Äì however, unable to pick the quantity in the delivery, even though stock is available.

entry.title: Re: Help creating a Data Provider for Forms created in AD...
entry.content:
Hi,
maybe you could have a look at the recently published note: https://me.sap.com/notes/3650179 

Summary:
For the current release 2508 it requires the following features for the service definitions to be used in ADT Forms dialog:

  • Service definition / Leading entity name needs to be defined completely in uppercase
  • For Service definition add following annotation: @ObjectModel.leadingEntity.name: 'LEADING_ENTITY'
  • For Leading Entity add the following annotation on top: @ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: [ #OUTPUT_FORM_DATA_PROVIDER  ]

This is obviously not ideal from usability perspective. We will improve this in the following releases.

Best regards
Pascal

entry.title: The Future of AI in Procurement: Why Your Best Colleague Might Be a Bot
entry.content:
I was halfway through an evening run with my husband when I realized something that stopped me in my tracks‚Äîliterally. For the past ten minutes, he'd been telling me about a conversation he'd had about a core project at work. He described how his colleague Chad had helped him think through a complex problem, offered creative solutions, and even challenged some of his assumptions. The advice was spot-on, and the conversation was completely natural and engaging. 

Then it hit me: "Chad" wasn't a new team member. Chad was a chatbot. 

This moment crystallized something I've been thinking about a lot lately as I work with procurement leaders around the world. AI isn't coming to procurement‚Äîit's already here. And the transformation it's bringing to complex processes like RFP creation and supplier management is more profound than most realize. 

The Invisible Revolution 

When AI works as intended, it operates seamlessly behind the scenes, supporting us to move further, faster, and with less stress. Think about the last time you wrote a text message. Those predictive words that appeared as you typed: that's AI. When your bank flags a suspicious transaction before you even notice it‚ÄîAI again. How about the customer service chat that helped you resolve your issue at midnight? That‚Äôs most likely an AI-powered system. 

Just last month, I was speaking with members of a team focused on digital solutions for procurement at a Fortune 500 company. We were discussing their advanced sourcing solutions when I mentioned AI capabilities. They said, "Oh, we're not using AI yet" but after I asked a few questions about their current RFP processes, it became clear they were leveraging advanced AI for sourcing events; they just didn't realize it. 

This invisibility is actually AI's greatest success story, particularly in complex procurement workflows where multiple technologies work together to streamline what were once manual, time-intensive processes. 

The RFP Challenge: Where AI Shows Its True Value 

Let me share a story that illustrates exactly why this matters for procurement professionals.  

I still remember creating my first sourcing event‚Äîit was for trade show booths, and I had no idea what I was getting into. The research alone took days, from finding the right vendors to writing questions and tracking all the details. I easily spent two weeks just drafting the RFP. Then came the real challenge: manually reviewing each proposal, pulling key data points, and building comparison spreadsheets. I constantly worried I was missing something important. 

According to SAP benchmark data, * after gathering initial requirements and shortlisting suppliers, the average procurement team then spends about 6 hours just populating and researching spend categories to create RFPs‚Äîbut with AI, they spend only 2 hours, which is a 70% reduction.  


This is exactly why AI represents such a game-changer for procurement.  

When AI Becomes Your Colleague 

Which brings me back to Chad and my eye-opening run. My husband‚Äôs story illustrates something profound happening in workplaces everywhere: AI is becoming less of a tool and more of a teammate. But the real magic happens when AI understands the context and complexity of your specific business needs. 

This is true in our personal lives as well. For example, my family recently took the trip of a lifetime to Greece. While we were exploring, we found ourselves standing before Zeus's temple with only a basic map. My husband pulled out his phone and told our AI assistant: "I'm on vacation with my family at Zeus's temple. We only have a map to guide us. Can you tell us the history of where we are?" 

Within minutes, our digital guide‚Äîwhom we playfully nicknamed "Uncle Chad"‚Äîprovided us with rich historical context and details that brought the ancient stones to life. The key was context. Our AI companion understood where we were and what we needed, and delivered exactly the right information at the right moment. 

This same contextual intelligence is what makes AI transformative for RFP processes and Statement of Work development. Instead of spending weeks building sourcing events from scratch, imagine describing your needs in natural language and having an AI partner that understands your organization's templates, supplier network, and approval workflows.

Joule: Your AI Sourcing Partner  

If I'd had Joule's Sourcing Agent when I was building my first RFP, I wouldn‚Äôt have spent so much time researching options and building the content from scratch. Instead, I would have simply described what I needed‚Äîthe same way I explained it to my manager when asking to extend the project timeline. 

Sourcing Agent transforms RFP creation through conversational AI. It pulls from your organization's templates, applies standard terms, identifies relevant suppliers from your network, sets up evaluation criteria, and configures approval workflows.  

Beyond sourcing events, Joule serves as your strategic procurement partner. It can help you manage approvals, research past purchases, select the right templates, and support daily supplier management activities. Through our Business Data Cloud, Joule has access to centralized, harmonized business data that provides the contextual insights you need to make sense of complex procurement scenarios. 

Joule Studio takes this even further, allowing procurement teams to build custom AI agents for specific business needs with drag-and-drop simplicity. Need an agent that specializes in contract analysis for your industry? Or one that understands your unique supplier onboarding process? You can create these specialized assistants without coding, tailored to match your specific procurement workflows. 

Navigating the Challenges 

AI isn't perfect, and there are valid concerns around it today. People wonder: How does it really work? Will it "hallucinate" and give me incorrect information? After all, AI systems aren't programmed to say, "I don't know"; they're designed to provide answers, even when those answers might be based on incomplete or biased training data. There are also privacy and security concerns, as well as limitations in contextual understanding. The job displacement question looms large too.  

However, the evidence suggests AI augments rather than replaces procurement expertise. The professionals thriving with AI are those who understand its capabilities and limitations, know how to ask the right questions, and use AI to amplify their strategic thinking rather than replace it. 

The Path Forward: Start Now 

We're already using AI in procurement, whether we realize it or not. The key is to lean in now. Start with manageable use cases like RFP creation, learn how these tools work, and discover how they enhance your processes. 

What sets SAP apart is our deep grounding in business processes and data, an open and extensible framework, and built-in security and compliance, which is underpinned by our commitment to ethical AI development. SAP leads the industry in responsible AI practices, ensuring the trust and integrity that procurement organizations need when handling sensitive information, like supplier data and contract information. 

 

I hope you‚Äôll join our September 18 webinar, ‚ÄúAI In Action: Practical Use Cases and Adoption Strategies for Procurement,‚Äù with me and Pierre Mitchell at Spend Matters. We'll discuss how AI in procurement can optimize resources, time, and budget, and explore how Joule can become your organization's newest team member.  

 

 

*Source: SAP Value Management. Numbers assumed for consumer products company with ‚Ç¨1billion in revenue and 2,000 employees; annual benefits result from one or more value drivers.

entry.title: Re: Business Partner Relationship WebService Inbound
entry.content:
Hello @Simon 

You‚Äôre right, in your key mapping, you see entries with the identifier ‚ÄúExternal ID,‚Äù but the standard key mapping framework in Public Cloud currently only supports InternalID for BP replication and relationship mapping. The ExternalID identifier appears in the mapping tables, but it isn‚Äôt processed by the standard integration logic.

That‚Äôs why the lookup is failing in your case; it‚Äôs simply not in scope at the moment. If you want to work with external IDs, you‚Äôd need either an enhancement option, such as via BAdI in DRC/MDI integration, or adjust your mapping so that the InternalID is used as the anchor key.

In a nutshell, you've got it right. The External ID is stored, but it's not currently being evaluated by the standard process.

Check-Key Mapping Replication help

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: New templates for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration: enhancing the custom receiver determination
entry.content:
As mentioned in one of my last blog post New integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration, we have added two new templates in one of our new integration packages, so actually the Cloud Integration Pipeline - Templates package where we ship templates for the scenario-specific integration flows and custom exits to support the Pipeline for Cloud Integration.

Both new templates can be used to implement an alternative approach for custom receiver and receiver interface determination. Depending on your specific requirements or boundary conditions, you can call a custom integration flow to determine the list of receivers and interfaces instead of the default of running an XSLT mapping stored in the Partner Directory.

Custom receiver and receiver interface determination has been supported before with the more generic template Pipeline v2 Template Step04 - Custom Receiver Determination. Now, we have added the following two templates, namely:

  • The template Pipeline v2 Template Step04 - Custom Receiver and Interface Determination via Extended Receiver Determination has been added for an option to implement custom receiver determination based on a message mapping and by maintaining exchange properties for the interface determination. A similar approach is applied in the SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration migration tool when selecting the Pipeline migration approach.
  • The template Pipeline v2 Template Step04 - Custom Receiver and Interface Determination via Exchange Properties allows you to implement custom receiver and interface determination by maintaining exchange properties. A similar approach is applied in the SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration migration tool when selecting the standard migration approach for the Recipient List and Content-Based-Router patterns.

In the following, I will show you how the two new approaches can be exemplarily configured.

Option using Mapping and Exchange Properties

In this option, the custom receiver determination is based on a message mapping resulting in an XML message containing the list of receivers. By maintaining corresponding exchange properties and running a Groovy script, the interfaces are added to the beforehand created XML message.

Note that this option can be used as alternative to the Reuse Extended Receiver Determination in case you want to migrate an integration scenario on SAP Process Orchestration that already uses the extended receiver determination. Other than the Reuse Extended Receiver Determination option, this option results into a combined receiver and interface XML message and hence is also supported in the integrated messaging runtime.

The custom integration flow looks as follows: In a content modifier step, you have to configure the parameters and XPaths for the interface determination. Then you run your message mapping to determine the list of receivers. This results into an XML message with all receivers that the message should sent to. By the way, you need to define the configuration before you run the message mapping because the message mapping will overwrite your payload which is needed in the content modifier. Finally, you run a script to add the receiver interfaces to the receiver nodes based on your configuration.

In the content modifier, for each potential receiver <Receiver name> from the Receivers XML and for each condition for the interface determination with index <Index number> starting from 1 on, you need to maintain the following exchange parameters adhering to the naming convention:

  • SAP-IFDET-<Receiver name>~IFIndex<Index number> where you specify the XPath condition for the interface condition
  • SAP-IFENDPT-<Receiver name>~IFIndex<Index number> where you specify the ProcessDirect endpoint of the corresponding scenario-specific outbound flow
  • SAP-IFNAME-<Receiver name>~IFIndex<Index number> where you specify the receiver interface name (this is an optional parameter)

To specify the behavior for the case that the receivers XML message doesn't contain any node and no receiver could be determined, create the following parameters:

  • SAP-NOREC: could be either Ignore, Error, or Default
  • SAP-NOREC-Default: in case of Default, specify default receiver name

If the default receiver is not in the list of already specified receivers, you need to create the corresponding parameters SAP-IFDET-Default~IFIndex<Index number>, SAP-IFENDPT-Default~IFIndex<Index number>, and SAP-IFNAME-Default~IFIndex<Index number>.

Here, an example of the configuration that the script uses to add the interfaces to the Receivers XML. In our example, we have 3 receivers, each receiver has one interface only with actual no condition so we specify the XPath true(). The default type is Default and the default receiver is already configured, so no need to create the default receiver specific parameters.

Here, an example of a message mapping which builds the Receivers XML message with the list of potential receivers.

 

The Groovy script customInterfaceDeterminationViaXProperties then adds the interfaces to the beforehand created XML message.

Option using Exchange Properties

In this option, you can implement a combined custom receiver and interface determination by maintaining exchange properties and running two Groovy scripts. The first Groovy script customReceiverDeterminationViaXProperties creates an XML message containing the list of receivers based on the corresponding configuration parameters. The second Groovy script customInterfaceDeterminationViaXProperties adds the interfaces to the previously created XML message based on the corresponding configuration parameters.

For the receiver and interface determination, you need to maintain the corresponding exchange properties in the content modifier following the naming convention:

For each receiver <Receiver name>, create the following exchange property:

  • SAP-DYNREC-<Receiver name> where you specify the XPath condition for the receiver determination

The parameters for the interface determination are the same like above.

Here, an example of the configuration that the scripts use to create the combined receivers and interfaces XML. It's the same example like above, in addition to above we have added the XPaths for the receiver determinations.

For more details, see Custom Receiver Determination.

entry.title: Re: Compensation Planning simplified with MDF Integration

You are only allowed to configure custom MDF objects in an EC enabled template as the mappings are populated through employmentInfo object. They can be used to control eligibility; however, EC needs to be enabled.

Gurusimran

entry.title: Re: Planned Delivery Date does not update from WM to ERP...
entry.content:
Hi @mconstanzo 

Thank you for your question. I hope this delayed response still provides some support.

what you observe in your screenshots is standard behaviour in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

  • The Planned Delivery Date in the inbound delivery header (app Change Inbound Deliveries ‚Äì Deliveries) is an executional field used for warehouse and goods receipt planning.
  • The Delivery Date on the item level (seen in VL32N or equivalent backend view) is tied to the purchase order schedule line and drives MRP and Manage Material Coverage.

Here are some key points you should know:

  • Changing only the Planned Delivery Date in the inbound delivery does not update the purchase order or ERP-side delivery item date.
  • MRP and the Manage Material Coverage app will still take the PO schedule line date as the planning driver.
  • Replication is triggered when certain fields (e.g. carrier, location) are updated, but not for delivery date alone.

Here is a standard solution you can evaluate:

  • If the supplier‚Äôs confirmed date changes, update the PO schedule line either via Ariba Supplier Confirmation or PO change.
  • This ensures MRP and execution processes remain aligned.
  • The inbound delivery should not be used to adjust planning; it only reflects executional adjustments.

To summarise, planned Delivery Date change in inbound delivery equals logistics execution only. Purchase order schedule line equals planning & MRP control. The correct approach is to update PO via Ariba confirmation or PO change, not through inbound delivery.

Here are some references for more guidelines:

  • Inbound Delivery Processing in S/4HANA Cloud
  • Manage Material Coverage ‚Äì App Help

 

I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Composable Storefront SSR Profiling in SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

SSR profiling can be complex task and hard to debug. SSR profiling will help you to identify performance bottleneck and potential memory leak. This article will briefly show how it can be executed. 

 

In Cloud with Dynatrace

Dynatrace doesn't give detail trace but it can be good start for the investigation.

Application Observability > Profiling and Optimisation > Continuous CPU profiling > server.mpjs jsapp-* > Method hotspots 

It can a view on thread dump for JavaScript code execution. In below, we can see an example with ratio execution during specific windows time. High percentage means many threads go through this call trace.

 

Locally

Deeper analysis can be executed locally page by page. NodeJs/SSR is not supposed supporting directly end-user traffic. It is why single request profiling should be large enough to identify potential improvement.

 

Prerequisites

If your SSR execution is slow, it can fallback to CSR. Before the profiling, please ensure you setup a long timeout value in server.ts

const ngExpressEngine = NgExpressEngineDecorator.get(engine, {
  timeout: 10_000,
  ssrFeatureToggles: {
    avoidCachingErrors: true,
    limitCacheByMemory: true,
  },
});

Message that indicates CSR fallback

"message":"SSR rendering exceeded timeout 3000, 
fallbacking to CSR for /electronics-spa/en/USD/"

CSR fallback can be also caused by not verified SSL certificate indicated by this message

UNABLE_TO_VERIFY_LEAF_SIGNATURE

In this case, you have to update server.ts to ignore SSL signature verification like this

function run() {
  const port = process.env['PORT'] || 4000;
  process.env['NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED'] = '0';
...

 

Inspect

Edit package.json and update ssr startup line by adding --inspect option in NodeJs.

"scripts": {
    "ng": "ng",
    "start": "ng serve",
    "build": "ng build",
    "watch": "ng build --watch --configuration development",
    "test": "ng test",
    "start:ssr": "node --inspect dist/webshop/server/server.mjs",
    "build:ssr": "ng build"
 }

Then you can start your Composable Storefront in SSR mode and attach Chrome debugger

% npm run start:ssr
> webshop@0.0.0 start:ssr
> node --inspect dist/webshop/server/server.mjs

Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9229/5dc67436-a3d3-4480-9e01-6051684e7afe
For help, see: https://nodejs.org/en/docs/inspector
{"message":"[spartacus] SSR optimization engine initialized",...
Node Express server listening on http://localhost:4000
Debugger attached.

After that, you open Chrome with this following URL chrome://inspect/#devices

Click on inspect to get web developer console to analyse thread and memory dump. Start a recording and just after do frontend request on the page where you want to perform the analysis. In below, you can see example on HomePage from sample website : http://localhost:4000/electronics-spa/en/USD/

 

Profiling

Another approach is to execute NodeJS with --prof option

Start SSR with this following command

% node --prof dist/webshop/server/server.mjs

Load page you want to analyse, HomePage for example: http://localhost:4000/electronics-spa/en/USD/

Run NodeJs analyser on the thread log files generated during the rendering

node --prof-process isolate-*log > process.txt

Edit process.txt to read analyse report, in below in example

Statistical profiling result from isolate-0x148008000-60288-v8.log, 
(551 ticks, 523 unaccounted, 0 excluded).

 [Shared libraries]:
   ticks  total  nonlib   name

 [JavaScript]:
   ticks  total  nonlib   name
      3    0.5%    0.5%  Builtin: LoadIC_NoFeedback
      3    0.5%    0.5%  Builtin: InterpreterEntryTrampoline
...

 

Conclusion

SSR optimisation is not necessary for end-user traffic. However, it should be fast enough for responding in acceptable time to CDN system. Often between 1s to 5s is considering a respectable time. Over 5s, SSR profiling should be executed to understand where bottleneck is located : OCC API backend call, rendering, state management, and so on.

If you need more support, please don't hesitate to contact SAP Expert Services.

Please let us know the solution for it, so we can test it same for our issue

entry.title: Re: Not able to pick the quantity in the delivery
entry.content:
Root causes could be

Even though stock is available, the system may not allow picking because:

  • The stock is not in the correct stock type or storage location expected by the delivery.
  • The delivery item is trying to pick from unrestricted stock, but the returned goods were scrapped or posted to blocked stock.
  • The requirement type KE (MTO) expects stock tied to the original sales order item, not general inventory.

Areas to check

  • In VL02N, check if the storage location is populated in the delivery item. If not, the system won‚Äôt know where to pick from. You can manually enter the correct storage location or configure automatic determination
  • Use MB52 or MMBE to verify is the stock in unrestricted use?, is it in the correct plant + storage location? and is it tied to the original return order item (especially for MTO)?
  • In VL02N, check the delivery header and item for any blocks. Sometimes a delivery block inherited from the return order can prevent picking.

To fix this, assuming that the stock is available but not being picked:

  • Try manually assigning the storage location in VL02N.
  • If the stock is tied to the return order item, ensure the SD-FC delivery is referencing that correctly.
  • If needed, transfer stock from blocked to unrestricted using MB1B with movement type 343 or MSR_INSPWH (if inspection is involved).

entry.title: Re: MANAGE REPAYMENT REQUEST APP NOT FOUND

entry.title: Re: Decentralized EWM. ID created against a STO is receiv...
entry.content:
What‚Äôs happening behind the scenes is even without explicit inspection setup in ERP (no inspection type, no Q-group), EWM can still trigger a quality inspection document if certain conditions are met in the EWM configuration. Here's why:

1. Inspection Object Type (IOT) Configuration in EWM
In Decentralized EWM, inspection documents are created based on Inspection Object Types (IOTs). If your system has IOTs like IOT 4 (Inbound Delivery) or IOT 5 (Recurring Inspection) active, EWM may still generate inspection documents‚Äîeven if ERP isn‚Äôt expecting them.

2. Inspection Rule in EWM
Even if no inspection rule is explicitly assigned to the material, a generic or default inspection rule might be active at the warehouse level. These rules can be triggered based on Document type (e.g., inbound delivery from STO), Partner or vendor, Product group or warehouse process type

3. QI02 Status in EWM
Status QI02 means, Inspection document created in EWM, but no inspection lot exists in ERP. This typically happens when ERP doesn‚Äôt have an inspection type assigned to the material. The integration between EWM and ERP for QM is incomplete or misconfigured. The event linkage or BAdI that triggers inspection lot creation in ERP is missing or inactive.

To fix this what you can do is

  • In EWM, go to /SCWM/QINSP and review the inspection document. Check if an inspection rule is active for the product or warehouse. Review IOT settings under SPRO ‚Üí Extended Warehouse Management ‚Üí Quality Management ‚Üí Define Inspection Object Types
  • In ERP, Check the material master, is inspection type 01 or 04 assigned? Is QM activated for the plant?
  • Use QA32 or QVM2 to verify if any inspection lot exists. If not, ensure the event linkage between EWM and ERP is active BAdI QEVA_INSPLOT_CREATE or similar should be implemented to create inspection lots in ERP from EWM triggers.

If you want to prevent this behavior entirely, you can:

  • Deactivate the inspection rule or IOT in EWM for STO-based inbound deliveries.
  • Or, fully configure ERP QM so that inspection lots are created and processed properly.

entry.title: Re: Error TELNET conection Validity of certificate SSL
entry.content:
I believe that message isn't an error, but an alert about one certificate stored on the system PSE just about to expire. 

You can run the report SSF_ALERT_CERTEXPIRE (t-code SA38) to find which one is.

entry.title: Re: Include a field to FIORI app Mass change of purchase...
entry.content:
Why you can't see item fields in Adapt UI is because, in the Public Cloud edition, the app is built with restricted extensibility:

  • Adapt UI only allows changes to the header section.
  • The item section is not exposed for UI adaptation or field extension.
  • Even if you've added a custom field (like Requisitioner) to the PO item via the Custom Fields and Logic app, it won‚Äôt appear in the mass change app unless SAP has explicitly enabled it in the backend CDS view.

Do the following:

1. Check the Business Context of Your Custom Field
Make sure your field was added under Business Context: Procurement: Purchasing Document Item (MM_PURDOC_ITEM). This is correct for item-level fields.

2. Verify CDS View Enablement
SAP uses specific CDS views to expose fields in Fiori apps. In Public Cloud, you cannot manually extend these views. If the field isn‚Äôt exposed in the relevant CDS view used by the mass change app, it won‚Äôt be available‚Äîeven if it exists in the backend. You can check SAP Note 3592364 which confirms ‚ÄúIt is not possible to extend the app with new fields. Backend is hardcoded with the fields available.‚Äù

3. Alternative Workaround
If you need to mass-update item-level fields like Requisitioner, consider using Excel-based mass upload via the Manage Purchase Orders app., or Creating a custom RAP-based Fiori app that allows item-level mass changes or Raising a feature request via SAP Influence Portal if this is a recurring business need.

entry.title: Define Percentage/Quantity Overhead in Public Cloud
entry.content:
Please help to guide how to define Percentage/Quantity Overhead Rate in S/4HANA Public Cloud.

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Define Percentage/Quantity Overhead in Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,


The Overhead rates in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are defined in the configuration activity (SSCUI) 102922 - "Define Costing Sheets". There you will be able to define the overhead amounts in the rows, and set the percentage or quantity-based overhead rates. Kindly refer to the below SAP Help Portal documents for details:

Costing Sheet
Costing Sheet Configuration: FAQ


Best Regards,
SAP Support
